section: Importance of Assigning Results to Objects
text:
Importance of Assigning Results to Objects
In R, it‚Äôs important to assign results to objects to store the values and use them later in your analysis. Think of an object as a named storage location for your data or calculations.

Consider this calculation:

sum_result = 99 + 1



Here, we assign the result of 99 + 1 to an object called sum_result using the assignment operator = (some people use <- ‚Ä¶ the community discuss about this here and here).


Now, whenever you need the value, you can just use sum_result instead of retyping 99 + 1.








Note


In coding, it‚Äôs good practice to use only lower case and ‚Äú_‚Äù or ‚Äú.‚Äù for names (snake_case).

title: Introduction to R: the basics
text:
Exercise 1 (‚è± 10 mins):

Creating a Sequence:

Create a sequence of numbers that are multiples of 5, starting from 0 and ending at 50.
Hint: Use the seq() function.

Compute the Mean:

Calculate the mean of the sequence you created in step 2.

Logical Test and Conditional Computation:

Check if all elements in your sequence are greater than zero.
Then compute the mean around this new object with only logical elements.

Adding Comments:

Add comments to your code to explain what each step is doing.
Hint: Use # at the beginning of a line to make it a comment.

title: Introduction to R: the basics
text:
Solutions

# Step 1: Creating a Sequence
# Create a sequence of numbers that are multiples of 5, from 0 to 50.
# Use the seq() function to generate the sequence and assign it to an object named 'sequence'.
sequence <- seq(from = 0, to = 50, by = 5)

# Print the sequence to verify it was created correctly.
print(sequence) # Output: [1] 0 5 10 15 20 25 30 35 40 45 50


# Step 2: Compute the Mean
# Calculate the mean of the sequence created above using the mean() function.
mean_sequence <- mean(sequence)

# Print the mean to verify the calculation.
print(mean_sequence) # Output: [1] 27.5


# Step 3: Logical Test and Conditional Computation
# Check if all elements in the sequence are greater than zero.
# Use the ">" operator and assign the result to a new object named 'logical_test'.
logical_test <- sequence > 0

# Print the logical test result to see which elements satisfy the condition.
print(logical_test) # Output: [1] FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE

# Compute the mean of the logical test result.
# This will treat TRUE as 1 and FALSE as 0.
mean_logical <- mean(logical_test)

# Print the mean of the logical test result.
print(mean_logical) # Output: [1] 0.9090909

Writing in .csv Format is (Almost) Always a Good Choice

For most cases, writing data in .csv format is a reliable and widely compatible option.
I recommend using the fwrite function from the data.table package for its speed and efficiency.



Below, we save various datasets into the Intermediate folder using fwrite:

Writing .rds Files (For R Objects)

The .rds format is specifically designed for saving R objects. It is useful for saving intermediate results, objects, or data.
We‚Äôll explore this format in more detail later, but here‚Äôs a quick example:



# Example
base::saveRDS(data, "data_tax.rds")



Writing .xlsx Files (For Excel Compatibility): To save data in Excel format (.xlsx), use the writexl package. It is lightweight and doesn‚Äôt require external dependencies.


# Example
writexl::write_xlsx(data, "data_tax.xlsx")




Writing .parquet Files (For Large Datasets): The .parquet format is a columnar storage format that is highly efficient for both reading and writing large datasets (typically >1GB).


# Example

title: Data Wrangling with dplyr
text:
What is dplyr?

dplyr is a grammar of data manipulation - providing a consistent set of verbs to solve most data manipulation challenges.




The Core Verbs üß∞

select() ‚Üí Choose columns
filter() ‚Üí Choose rows

mutate() ‚Üí Create columns
summarize() ‚Üí Aggregate data
arrange() ‚Üí Sort data
















Note


Think of these verbs as actions you perform on your data - just like in natural language!

title: Data Wrangling with dplyr
text:
The Magic Pipe: %>%

The pipe operator %>% (or |> in base R) allows us to chain operations together.


Without the pipe:

# Nested functions - hard to read!
arrange(filter(select(data, firm_id, vat_outputs), vat_outputs > 10000), desc(vat_outputs))



With the pipe:

# Clear, readable workflow!
data %>%
  select(firm_id, vat_outputs) %>%
  filter(vat_outputs > 10000) %>%
  arrange(desc(vat_outputs))









Tip


Read the pipe as ‚Äúthen‚Äù - take data, then select columns, then filter rows, then arrange!
